Developers should use Android App Links [3]  and iOS Universal Links [4]  to provide a secure binding between URIs and applications, preventing malicious applications from intercepting redirections. Additionally, for OAuth use cases, PKCE [2]  should be used to prevent use of stolen authorization codes.
iOS 11 introduced a first-come-first-served principle for URIs, allowing only the prior installed app to be launched via the URI. [1]  Android 6 introduced App Links.
Users should be instructed to not open links in applications they don’t recognize.
If running on a Huawei device,  Desert Scorpion  adds itself to the protected apps list, which allows it to run with the screen off. [1]
Dvmap  can enable installation of apps from unknown sources. [2]
GoldenEagle  has modified or configured proxy information. [3]
Mandrake  can enable app installation from unknown sources. [4]
SilkBean  has attempted to trick users into enabling installation of applications from unknown sources. [3]
TianySpy  can install malicious configurations on iPhones to allow malware to be installed via Ad Hoc distribution. [5]
Windshift  has installed malicious MDM profiles on iOS devices as part of Operation ROCK. [6]
XLoader for iOS  has been installed via a malicious configuration profile. [7]

YiSpecter  has used fake Verisign and Symantec certificates to bypass malware detection systems.  YiSpecter  has also signed malicious apps with iOS enterprise certificates to work on non-jailbroken iOS devices. [8]

On iOS, the  allowEnterpriseAppTrust  and  allowEnterpriseAppTrustModification  configuration profile restrictions can be used to prevent users from installing apps signed using enterprise distribution keys.

Mobile OSes have implemented measures to make it more difficult to trick users into installing untrusted certificates and configurations. iOS 10.3 and higher add an additional step for users to install new trusted CA certificates and configuration profiles. On Android, apps that target compatibility with Android 7 and higher (API Level 24) default to only trusting CA certificates that are bundled with the operating system, not CA certificates that are added by the user or administrator, hence decreasing their susceptibility to successful adversary-in-the-middle attack. [9] [10]

Typically, insecure or malicious configuration settings are not installed without the user's consent. Users should be advised not to install unexpected configuration settings (CA certificates, iOS Configuration Profiles, Mobile Device Management server provisioning).
Security updates may contain patches to integrity checking mechanisms that can detect unauthorized hardware modifications.
XcodeGhost  was injected into apps by a modified version of Xcode (Apple's software development tool). [2] [3]
Application developers should be cautious when selecting third-party libraries to integrate into their application.
AbstractEmu  can check device system properties to potentially avoid running while under analysis. [1]

Android/AdDisplay.Ashas  can check that the device IP is not in the range of known Google IP addresses before triggering the payload and can delay payload deployment to avoid detection during testing and avoid association with unwanted ads. [2]
Anubis  has used motion sensor data  to attempt to determine if it is running in an emulator. [3]
Cerberus  avoids being analyzed by only activating the malware after recording a certain number of steps from the accelerometer. [4]
Chameleon  can perform system checks to verify if the device is rooted or has ADB enabled and can avoid execution if found. [5]
Dendroid  can detect if it is being ran on an emulator. [6]
FakeSpy  can detect if it is running in an emulator and adjust its behavior accordingly. [7]
Ginp  can determine if it is running in an emulator. [8]
HenBox  can detect if the app is running on an emulator. [9]

Mandrake  can evade automated analysis environments by requiring a CAPTCHA on launch that will prevent the application from running if not passed. It also checks for indications that it is running in an emulator. [10]
Rotexy  checks if it is running in an analysis environment. [11]
TERRACOTTA  checks whether its call stack has been modified, an indication that it is running in an analysis environment, and if so, does not decrypt its obfuscated strings [12] .
TrickMo  can detect if it is running on a rooted device or an emulator. [13]
Windshift  has deployed anti-analysis capabilities during their Operation BULL campaign. [14]
WolfRAT  can perform primitive emulation checks. [15]
Exobot  can obtain a list of installed applications and can detect if an antivirus application is running, and close it if it is. [1]
Gustuff  checks for antivirus software contained in a predefined list. [2]

Android 11 introduced privacy enhancements to package visibility, filtering results that are returned from the package manager. iOS 12 removed the private API that could previously be used to list installed applications on non-app store applications. [3]
iOS users should be instructed to not download applications from unofficial sources, as applications distributed via the Apple App Store cannot list installed applications on a device.
Adups  was pre-installed on Android devices from some vendors. [1] [2]

A Linux kernel distributed by  Allwinner  reportedly contained an simple backdoor that could be used to obtain root access. It was believed to have been left in the kernel by mistake by the authors. [3]

CHEMISTGAMES  has been distributed as updates to legitimate applications. This was accomplished by compromising legitimate app developers, and subsequently gaining access to their Google Play Store developer account. [4]
In at least one case,  Stealth Mango  may have been installed using physical access to the device by a repair shop. [5]
Triada  was added into the Android system by a third-party vendor identified as Yehuo or Blazefire during the production process. [6] [7]
Security updates may contain patches that inhibit system software compromises.
Ensure Verified Boot is enabled on devices with that capability.
Twitoor  can be controlled via Twitter. [1]
BusyGasper  can be controlled via IRC using freenode.net servers. [1]
Mandrake  has used Firebase for C2. [2]
TERRACOTTA  has used Firebase for C2 communication. [3]

ANDROIDOS_ANSERVER.A  uses encrypted content within a blog site for part of its command and control. Specifically, the encrypted content contains URLs for other servers to be used for other aspects of command and control. [1]
Anubis  can retrieve the C2 address from Twitter and Telegram. [2] [3]
Red Alert 2.0  can fetch a backup C2 domain from Twitter if the primary C2 is unresponsive. [4]
XLoader for Android  has fetched its C2 address from encoded Twitter names, as well as Instagram and Tumblr. [5]
